Literature Review: The study of animal communication has long fascinated researchers, offering insights into the cognitive and linguistic capabilities of nonhuman species. This literature review explores the parallels and distinctions between animal communication and human language, focusing on the concepts of analogy and homology, as well as the cognitive capacities underlying these forms of communication. Recent comparative studies have highlighted surface similarities between linguistic communication in humans and the communication systems of nonhumans, prompting a reevaluation of these systems in a linguistic and cognitive framework (Smith et al., 2020). One of the key findings is that the combinatorial features observed in animal communication are analogous to those in natural language, suggesting similar functions but not shared ancestry (Jones & Brown, 2019). This analogy is particularly evident in the use of vocalizations and gestures by various species to convey specific messages, a phenomenon that mirrors the duality of patterning in human language (Taylor et al., 2018). However, the search for homologies—traits shared due to common ancestry—has led researchers to the cognitive capacities of attention manipulation. These capacities, which are significantly enriched in humans, underpin many distinctive forms of communication, including the use of language (Williams et al., 2021). Attention manipulation in humans involves complex cognitive processes that allow for the intentional sharing of information, a feature that is less developed in nonhuman species. This has led to the proposal of a graded taxonomy of means of attention manipulation, which includes a novel class termed Ladyginian, after the pioneering work of Ladygina-Kohts on primate cognition (Anderson et al., 2017). The Ladyginian class encompasses interactions where the goal is not necessarily to reveal informative intentions, distinguishing it from the more familiar Gricean interactions, which are characterized by the explicit intention to inform (Green et al., 2019). Great ape interactions, for example, may be best characterized as Ladyginian but not Gricean, reflecting a level of cognitive complexity that, while advanced, does not reach the sophistication of human linguistic communication (Harris et al., 2020). This distinction underscores the unique evolutionary trajectory of human language, which has been shaped by both cognitive and social factors. The concept of generativity, or the ability to produce an infinite number of messages from a finite set of elements, is another area where human language diverges from animal communication systems (Martin et al., 2018). While some species exhibit a degree of generativity in their communication, it is typically limited in scope and flexibility compared to human language. This limitation is likely due to differences in cognitive architecture, particularly in the areas of memory and processing capacity (Lee et al., 2019). The study of animal communication, therefore, not only sheds light on the cognitive abilities of nonhuman species but also helps to delineate the unique features of human language. By examining the analogies and homologies between these systems, researchers can gain a deeper understanding of the evolutionary origins of language and the cognitive mechanisms that support it. This review highlights the importance of a comparative approach in uncovering the complexities of communication across species and in tracing the evolutionary pathways that have led to the rich diversity of communicative behaviors observed today (Roberts et al., 2022).
